title: Raja Ravi Varma
summary: Raja Ravi Varma (1848â€“1906) was a prominent Indian painter and artist celebrated for his unique fusion of European academic art with Indian sensibility and iconography. He significantly broadened public engagement with fine arts by making affordable lithographs of his paintings widely available, profoundly shaping artistic tastes. His depictions of Hindu deities and scenes from Indian epics garnered immense acclaim. Born into an aristocratic family in Kilimanoor, Travancore, and closely related to the Travancore royal family, he was officially conferred the personal title 'Raja' by Lord Curzon, highlighting his stature and influence.
key_points: Pioneering Indian painter known for synthesizing European academic art with Indian sensibility and iconography.
Instrumental in democratizing art by making affordable lithographs of his paintings accessible to the public.
Significantly enhanced his reach and influence, shaping artistic tastes and increasing common people's involvement with fine arts.
Received profound acclaim for his religious depictions of Hindu deities and works based on Indian epic poetry and Puranas.
Part of the royal family of Parappanad and closely related to the Travancore royal family, conferred the title 'Raja' by Lord Curzon.
timeline: 29 April 1848: Born as M. R. Ry. Ravi Varma, Koil Thampuran of Kilimanoor, in Travancore.
1860: His younger brother, Raja Varma, also a painter, was born.
Unspecified date: Conferred the personal title 'Raja' by Viceroy and Governor-General of India, Lord Curzon.
Unspecified date: Two of his granddaughters were adopted into the Travancore royal family.

applications: Mass reproduction and wide dissemination of fine art to the general public through lithography.
Defined and shaped artistic tastes and preferences among common people in India.
Increased public engagement and involvement with fine arts, moving it beyond aristocratic circles.
current_status: Raja Ravi Varma's works are highly regarded as prime examples of the successful fusion of European academic art with traditional Indian iconography. His religious depictions continue to receive profound acclaim, and his legacy as a pioneer in making art accessible through lithography endures. His contributions remain a significant part of Indian art history.
future_prospects: Future prospects include continued academic study and research into his unique artistic synthesis and cultural impact. His artworks and lithographs are expected to be preserved and exhibited in museums globally, ensuring his legacy. His distinctive artistic style and methods are likely to continue inspiring contemporary Indian artists to explore blends of traditional and modern forms.
